#Text=Wikinews interviews 17-year-old author of ' LEGO Heavy Weapons '
#Text=Sunday , June 17 , 2012
#Text=17-year-old Jack Streat has accomplished something some people spend a lifetime reaching for : he 's a published author .
#Text=Streat 's book , " LEGO Heavy Weapons : Build Working Replicas of Four of the World 's Most Impressive Guns " , was released in May by indie publisher No Starch Press .

column1: #Text=The book features detailed drawings and explanations on how to build highly sophisticated working models of 4 assault weapons , including the Desert Eagle handgun , among others .
#Text=Wikinews interviewed Jack , to learn more about his passion for building .
#Text=Interview
#Text=Jack Streat , with a LEGO weapon model .
#Text=First , how old are you now and how old were you when the book was published ?
#Text=Seventeen at the moment , as I was when the book was published .
#Text=I 'll be 18 in just over a month , though .
#Text=Who is the publisher of the book ?
#Text=No Starch Press , who 're based in San Francisco .
#Text=How long have you been serious about LEGOs ?
#Text=Well I ca n't remember a time when I have n't been building with [ LEGOs ] ...
#Text=as to being ' serious ' about it ( if I have n't always been ) , the major turning points would probably be when , at age thirteen I posted my first gun online .
#Text=Incidentally [ that one is ] also the first gun in the book .
#Text=I started working toward the book ... around October 2010 .
#Text=Are there any designers/creators who 've inspired you ?
#Text=Not particularly .

#Text=This may be due to the fact that most of my work was in replicating existing guns — which , of course , is n't quite the same as being inspired by someone and then designing something else from scratch .
#Text=Educationally , where are you : finished with high school ?
#Text=In college ?
#Text=Just entering my last week of A2 exams ( the last exams in school ) at the moment , and then after that ( well , in a few months ' time ) I 'm off to university !
#Text=What have your parents/family thought about your passions for LEGOs ?
#Text=They 've always encouraged it .

#Text=They 'd buy me LEGO for birthdays and Christmas and so on , and I always enjoyed showing them the latest thing I 'd built — of course I would n't be anywhere near where I am now without their support , so they must be okay with it !
#Text=With the publishing world , did you face any challenges in getting your book published ?

#Text=I was very lucky actually — Tyler Ortman , my editor , contacted me out of the blue ( also through YouTube 's messaging system ) and asked on behalf of No Starch if I 'd like to write a book of instructions for them to publish .
#Text=I 'd just started teaching myself how to use some CAD software for modelling LEGO creations , so I was all set , really .
#Text=Jack Streat , with a copy of his book , " LEGO Heavy Weapons " .

column1: #Text=Are you working on another book at present ?
#Text=Well I still have a few mechanism/gun ideas floating around in my head , but that 's simply ideas for more of the models I 've been building personally .
#Text=I 've got to get through university before I even consider the possibility , but after that , who knows ?
#Text=Have there been other activities/classes that have helped your LEGO work improve ?
#Text=Not really .
#Text=Just time , patience , and lots and lots of bricks !
#Text=Where can our readers see videos or other forms of your work ?
#Text=My YouTube channel has videos of most of the guns I 've built , but with very little textual description .
#Text=[ YouTube ]
#Text=and my MOCpages homepage has lots of information on all the guns I 've built ; they did n't all end up on YouTube . [
#Text=At MOCpages ]
#Text=there 's descriptive text and a set of pictures for each one .
